DOCNAME: CASE OF DEVLIN v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Civil proceedings;Article 6-1 - Access to court;Civil rights and obligations);Non-pecuniary damage - award (Article 41 - Non-pecuniary damage;Just satisfaction)
TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP In DATE , the applicant applied for a position as an administrative assistant with ORG , the lowest grade in the non - industrial civil service . He passed a written test but was not invited for interview at that stage . In DATE , the applicant was invited for interview , and was informed on DATE that he was being recommended for appointment “ subject to the satisfactory outcome of various pre - appointment enquiries ” . He was informed on DATE that he had been unsuccessful . No reasons were given .

CARDINAL . The applicant believed that the decision not to appoint him must have been taken on grounds of his religious beliefs – he is a NORP and a member of an association known as ORG – and not for any legitimate security ground . A number of his relatives are involved in public service in various capacities , and neither he nor any member of his family had ever been involved in any form of criminal activity . He had some unpleasant encounters with the police , but there was no question of proceedings against him . On CARDINAL occasion , the applicant lodged a complaint about his treatment by the police , which was resolved when the applicant was informed that the officers involved would be “ spoken to ” . According to the applicant , a further incident with the police occurred DATE after he was informed that his job application had been unsuccessful : a police officer at a vehicle checkpoint in GPE referred to the unsuccessful job application .

CARDINAL . The applicant made an application , through ORG , to ORG , alleging discrimination contrary to LAW GPE ) Act DATE ( “ the LAW ” ) . ORG affirmed that the refusal had been made on security grounds , and claimed that LAW did not therefore apply .

CARDINAL . On DATE , the Secretary of State for GPE issued a certificate under section DATE ( CARDINAL ) of LAW , certifying that the refusal of employment to the applicant was an act “ done for the purpose of safeguarding national security and of protecting public safety ” .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant attempted to challenge the Secretary of ORG ’s decision to issue the section CARDINAL certificate by way of an application for judicial review in ORG . Leave to apply for judicial review was granted on DATE .

CARDINAL . In the affidavits sworn on behalf of the Secretary of ORG , it was stated that , in accordance with the usual procedure , the security questionnaire completed by the applicant had been forwarded to ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) , which had provided security information relating to the applicant . This information was such that the assessing officer in the ORG ’s security branch had recommended that the applicant was unsuitable for employment in ORG .

CARDINAL . After an unsuccessful application for discovery , the application for judicial review was dismissed by Mr Justice PERSON in ORG on DATE . After referring , inter alia , to the judgment of Mr Justice PERSON of DATE in the case of ORG and Others and PERSON and Others ( judgment of DATE , Reports of Judgments and Decisions CARDINAL-IV , p. CARDINAL ) , he considered that :

“ the effect of section DATE ( CARDINAL ) as enacted is to remove entirely from the sphere of ORG legislation acts done for the purpose of safeguarding national security and protecting public order or safety . ... [ There ] may be occasions when the Secretary of ORG will choose not to invoke his powers under section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) and the ORG may investigate whether the act complained of was done for all or any of the purposes specified under LAW ( CARDINAL ) . Where a certificate has been validly issued under LAW ( CARDINAL ) , however , I do not believe that the ORG retains any role in the hearing or adjudication of the complaint . ”

CARDINAL . By virtue of ORG ( GPE ) Act DATE ( “ the LAW ” ) , it is unlawful for an employer to discriminate against a person on grounds of religious belief or political opinion in relation to employment in GPE , inter alia , by dismissing him or subjecting him to any other detriment .

CARDINAL . By virtue of section CARDINAL of LAW ( as amended by LAW ( GPE ) Act DATE ) , a complaint of unlawful discrimination may be presented to ORG , which is established by statute to investigate complaints of unlawful discrimination on grounds of religious belief or political opinion .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW ( as amended ) provides as follows :
“ ( CARDINAL ) The Fair Employment ( GPE ) Acts shall not apply to an act done for the purpose of safeguarding national security or protecting public safety or public order .

( CARDINAL ) A certificate signed by , or on behalf of the Secretary of ORG and certifying that an act specified in the certificate was done for the purpose mentioned in sub - section ( CARDINAL ) shall be conclusive evidence that it was done for that purpose .

( CARDINAL ) A document purporting to be a document such as is mentioned in sub - section ( CARDINAL ) shall be received in evidence and , unless the contrary is proved , shall be deemed to be such a certificate . ”
CARDINAL . LAW ( as amended by LAW ) provides as follows in section CARDINAL :

“ ( CARDINAL ) Subject to sub - section ( CARDINAL ) below it shall be unlawful for a Minister of the Crown ... and any authority or body listed ... in ... Schedule CARDINAL to LAW ( GPE ) DATE ... to discriminate , or aid , induce or incite another to discriminate , in the discharge of functions relating to GPE against any person or class of persons on the grounds of religious belief or political opinion . ...

( CARDINAL ) This section does not apply to any act or omission which is unlawful by virtue of ORG ( GPE ) Act DATE or would be unlawful but for some exception made by virtue of Part V of that Act . ”

CARDINAL . Schedule CARDINAL to LAW ( GPE ) DATE lists the departments and authorities subject to investigation by the Parliamentary Commissioner . The list includes ORG and all Government Departments , including ORG and Personnel . However , section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act falls within Part V of that Act . Accordingly , where a section CARDINAL certificate has been issued ( claiming an act was done for the purpose of safeguarding national security or protecting public safety or public order ) , section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE ( as amended ) has no effect .
